awd_titl_txt: EAGER: MAKER: Making Prosthetics for Kids - Socially Relevant Making to Catalyze Diversity and Engagement in STEM Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This exploratory research project is studying socially-relevant Making in the context of an on campus
university Makerspace. Project studies are developing best practice models of how
informal STEM learning through Making can be leveraged to improve the effectiveness of both
informal and formal learning approaches, as well as to increase retention and broaden
participation in STEM education for students and faculty. This is being studied across both
secondary and post-secondary levels in partnership with a local engineering-focused high school.
Project research is grounded in a specific socially-relevant challenge problem: designing and
fabricating prosthetic hands for children who need them. Challenge problem activities are
connected directly to real world context and outcomes in partnership with a nonprofit
organization that specializes in facilitating and providing 3D printed recreational prosthetic
hands free of charge for children with limb differences.

Project research is defining novel integrations of informal and formal STEM learning pathways,
providing case studies, learning materials, lessons learned, and scalable design templates for
learning ecosystems at other institutions. The focus on design thinking supports learning
benefits from cross-disciplinary interaction, particularly in interdisciplinary peer learning of
STEM concepts, exposing non-STEM learners to STEM concepts, and disrupting traditional
teacher-student roles. Project outcomes are catalyzing and sustaining diverse learner transitions
to a Maker STEM-based affinity identity by identifying best practice design patterns for learning,
focused by the challenge problem, which can be applied more generally to foster synergetic
interactions between formal and informal learning within educational environments.

por.por_cntn:
Makerspaces come in all shapes and sizes, but they are places where people can learn and practice 21st century skills in designing and creating new physical things such as DIY prosthetics, as well as to gain experience with a variety of tools for innovation such as 3D printers. The importance of such skills can be seen in emerging technologies for 3D printing everything from basic hooks and holders to food, cars, houses, and even bioprinting replacement organs for people.  Learning and experience with "making" is valuable both for individuals to develop next generation skills, as well as for society in terms of the innovations that emerge.

This project explored different ways to help connect people with making and makerspaces in order to promote learning, innovation, and workforce development. The overall approach was to develop activities and learning materials for different kinds of making, and then pilot test the activities both for classroom learning and for more informal learning such as opt-in workshops and events or participating in projects for social good.  As part of that, it was important to understand the issues and best practices in creating and fostering makerspace communities with support for both diversity and engagement. The project explored a variety of pathways in making, but it had a focus on DIY assistive technology, in particular on the challenge of designing and fabricating DIY prosthetic hands for children and families that need them.

The project developed a variety of learning activities and materials both for more general making engagement and also for addressing different aspects of the DIY assistive technology challenge.  The activities were used and refined through an extensive series of workshops with teachers and students in formal K-12 classroom settings, as well as in high-school senior projects and university capstone course projects.  For classroom students, this provided an introduction to making and its potential for addressing larger issues.  For teachers, this provided both professional development and activities and materials for ongoing classroom use. For students in longer-term projects this provided extensive training, mentorship, and experience in both service learning and innovation in addressing challenge problems for DIY assistive technology. The project also supported broader training and development through innovative making experiences in a series of team-based university/community events to showcase creativity in fabrication.  Moreover, the project provided comprehensive training and development for graduate and undergraduate student team members and collaborators. Throughout project activities, data and participant feedback were collected and analyzed to understand best practices in makerspace community development, providing lessons learned and guidance for both researchers and maker leaders.

The Helping Hand Project (HHP) is a regional non-profit organization whose mission is to support the limb difference community and people who wish to impact it.  This research project worked in partnership with HHP in order to engage with the limb difference community, provide training and development for HHP members, and to develop innovative designs for DIY prosthetic devices and supporting accessories. In conjunction with HHP, the project delivered numerous customized DIY prosthetic hands, arms, and accessories to kids and families who needed them, as well as engaging in outreach through regular events with participating families. 

Some aspects of the project were impacted by the pandemic.  But this also provided different opportunities in line with project goals for engagement and innovation through making.  In early-mid 2020, available project staff partnered with a grassroots community organization, CharlotteMEDI to provide research and development expertise around local digital fabrication of personal protective equipment (PPE) for healthcare providers. Project staff partnered with CharlotteMEDI in the development and production of 3D printed / laser cut components for face shields, helping the CharlotteMEDI group to deliver over 100K face shields directly to local healthcare organizations at a time of national PPE shortage. In addition, project staff developed new, publicly available designs for reusable PPE.
